text:
<!channel>,
maybe Sian said it in lecture:
You might arrive at a point where you want to write relatively complex code to achieve a goal with this Spotipy wrapper (for loops etc.) Before you do, having a look a what utilities Spotipy has to offer can really help and save you work - been there myself :slightly_smiling_face: <https://spotipy.readthedocs.io/en/2.16.1/#spotipy.client.Spotify>

Especially if your search the documentation for "get... " can be really helpful

text: I am running the function below on a list of 740 album IDs and the issue is that instead of compiling a list with all the albums, everything is overwritten by the [‘items’] of the last album in the list. Can anyone spot the mistake/gap I have here:

elements.text: I am running the function below on a list of 740 album IDs and the issue is that instead of compiling a list with all the albums, everything is overwritten by the [‘items’] of the last album in the list. Can anyone spot the mistake/gap I have here:

text:
1. introduce a list in which you collect all tracks `albumtracks = []` at the beginning at yellow,
2.  indent the purple part, 
3. at the end of the purple part, extend  `albumtracks` with that extend statement
4.  and then return `albumtracks` at the end.

elements.text: introduce a list in which you collect all tracks
albumtracks = []
at the beginning at yellow,
indent the purple part,
at the end of the purple part, extend
albumtracks
with that extend statement
and then return
albumtracks
at the end.

text:
i like to draw these things - follow down the function code as a process flow and you’ll likely see where you went wrong - without the indent, you would overwrite anything prior with the while argument. instead of saying *for* each album, keep grabbing the songs 100 at a time until we hit a search page with less than 100, you start that process, then scoot all the way to the last album because of the while, ignore all the other albums and start collecting tracks using the extend()

as in : for each sunny day i should put on suncream. BUT while its still sunny, lets wait to buy some suncream because it will be cheaper when it gets cold.

elements.text: i like to draw these things - follow down the function code as a process flow and you’ll likely see where you went wrong - without the indent, you would overwrite anything prior with the while argument. instead of saying
for

each album, keep grabbing the songs 100 at a time until we hit a search page with less than 100, you start that process, then scoot all the way to the last album because of the while, ignore all the other albums and start collecting tracks using the extend()

as in : for each sunny day i should put on suncream. BUT while its still sunny, lets wait to buy some suncream because it will be cheaper when it gets cold.

text:
Thanks <@U021UNQGZC4>, makes absolute sense. :slightly_smiling_face:

I went back to apply the changes for the function to get album_ids (since it used the same syntax) and got a bunch of more IDs as output compared to the first run.

However, now the tracks function has the same issue as before. I only get tracks for one album. Function has the same structure as per tips from <@U021WEXHN4E>. All that changed is the length of the input list. Not quite sure what the issue might be here. :confused:
